Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Good overall intro to contemporary bio.
I gained a working knowledge of biology (as a humanities student) and developed a keen interest in the sciences.
From this course, I gained the skill of considering the ethics behind the regulation of / dissemination of certain biological advancements such as genome editing, stem cell research, etc.
Basic biology knowledge -- less technical than AP, more issues-based
I learned a lot of important scientific concepts as well as more scientific literacy to understand science-related issues in society.
I learned a lot of basic biology and even some advanced bio. I learned a ton about DNA, the environment, genome sequencing, etc.
I gained a biological understanding for many issues that are very relevant to me today.
Not really anything.

This course was a great introduction to the scientific issues facing our society. After taking this course, I feel I have a better understanding of research science as a professional field, and the role of policy in the regulation of climate change, drug development, etc.
I learned about the basics of the biological world.
Good intro to biology, Im literate in biology now
This course was a good introduction into Biology for someone who has not taken science courses in the past.

I studied a variety of topics related to modern field in science and applications they may hold for future innovations. Such topics included DNA replication, RNA, epigenetics, genetically modified organisms, protein-misfolding diseases, global warming, and more.
I learned about the biological foundations of many topics in modern biology like stem cells and GMOs
Greater understanding of the fundamental elements of biology and their relation to modern issues.
I learned about prevalent diseases plaguing our community and the different ways community members are aiming to handle them.
I learned the basics of biology and science writing.
Basics about bio
I developed basic scientific literacy, both in terms of understanding biology and in terms of social and ethical issues today.
I learned about different aspects of biology and how it relates to the world
About basic biology
Some knowledge pertaining to biological concepts.

I learned a lot about different science topics. I enjoyed the pain and neurological subjects. We also discussed the relevancy of the topics in our lives today. On a broader note, I learned how to better organize my study guides.
A great intro to biology! Im not a stem person at all and his was the perfect class. Learned a bunch and was challenged only a small amlunt
biology
I learned a lot of basic information about biology that I always wanted to know. I learned a lot about key debates in the field, and I felt like all the knowledge I gained was useful.
A bit about biology in the world
Broad range of Bio topics, which everyone would benefit knowing.
Nothing.

I learned many crucial components of what makes our world function, as well as explored social issues surrounding contentious breakthroughs in the modern science community. This course taught me good active study skills, and also how to access and digest scientific research for my own understanding.
This course helped a lot in terms of just basic scientific/ biological understanding of a lot of issues that appear in the news a lot and such.
I learned a lot about biology, a lot more than I had actually anticipated.

Learned the biology concerning the newly-acquired biological capacities that pose ethical issues in political and civil regulation. It was taught extensively to my standard, but obviously short-sightedly in comparison to the TAs' and Professors'; and that is not to say that I do not value the information I have learned in any manner. The biological issues discussed were actually very intriguing and made more interesting by the philosophical implications of their regulation. When I signed up for the class, I did not think there would be as much focus as there was over the actual biological knowledge behind the issues; however, the exams are manageable because the lectures thoroughly teach the material, and I'm actually glad I am able to speak about some of the topics with more familiarity.
I learned the wonders of genetic biology.
Intro to bio, basic knowledge

I better learned about basic biological processes within the body and on the planet. I enjoyed learning about therapeutic practices changing the medical and biotechnological industries as well as ways to better interact with the world around me.

This course is a great overview and introductory course to the wide variety of topics that biology encompasses, and how it relates to society and politics today.  We learn about everything from the microbiome, to neurological diseases, to the basic functions of the cells, to climate change and how it impacts the world.

This course combines biology and ethics. You get presented with biological principles and explore their applications/relevance in medicine and everyday life. Subjects include GMOs, microbiota, cells, addiction, global warming, etc.

basic fundamental understanding of many biological processes including DNA replication, mutations & repair, sequencing, epigenetics; genetic modification and genome editing; cellular processes such as replication, cell death & cancer; and global warming
I felt like I gained a fuller knowledge of basic biology and also more about its real world application.
Basic biology
Learned the basics of biology and how to read/write about science
understanding of cellular activity, some organ systems in the human body, evolution, genetics, and environmental science

I learned a lot about basic biology, and its implications for the modern world. But the lectures were hard and helping me find the connection, they felt like two very different things that we had to learn separately before we understood the connection.  It was not super engaging.
Really gained a great background as to how to converse intellectually about relevant scientific issues.

I really enjoyed this class because of its relevance to modern scientific questions and dilemmas. I feel like I am more educated about problems and issues i will face in my personal life, and better equipped to face them.
I learnt about the major themes in biology that are shaping our world today, and a how to think about new biotechnology beyond the hype.
learned about the science as well as different practical and ethical issues behind different topics in biology
Better understanding of scientific issues that have a bearing on our lives, such as GMOs, cancer and climate change!

Strengths: The breadth of lecturers was great. Did a good job of relating the actual biology to contemporary issues.

Weaknesses: The actual biology is incredibly jargon-laden. I think it's fair to assume most people taking this course are non-stem majors, so it makes it tough to follow concepts when there are so many acronyms. This problem was most evident in the later parts of the semester (RNAi, Genetic engineering, specifically)
I would not improve this course -- it is already fantastic. I loved every lecture and learned very much in the process.

A strength of this course was that they TAs and lecturers took the mid-semester feedback into account when considering how to have more effective review sessions. A weakness of this course was that the lecture material often filled with a lot of vocabulary/concepts that just weren't explained. The lecturers and TAs often expected for non-science majors to be able to latch on to information they had never been exposed to. Another weakness was that the sections weren't tailored to the material we needed to know for the exams whatsoever and they felt like a waste of time in my opinion. I never fully understood the material, I simply memorized it, and I can say the same for many students I've spoken with.

It was frustrating at times to have no idea about section grades. Participation scores and reflection scores are hidden on Canvas, so it was hard to assess how well I was doing outside of lectures and exams.

I think section is a real strength. It helps you engage a lot better with the material covered in lecture. I think the consistency of lectures could definitely be improved. Some lecturers expected way more depth and minutiae, while others didn't. It made course-wide expectations more unclear.

This class is designed for students with limited science backgrounds, but it definitely did not feel like a basic biology class. It was a lot more science-heavy than I was expecting based on the course description.

I liked how the lectures were focused on individual problems. i liked that the tests were not cumulative (as each of these subjects / lectures were pretty all-encompassing); i would have liked to see a wider variety of topics covered. For example, I felt that some of the Englemann lectures focusing on basic cell bio were redundant when other professors recovered the same material as it related to their topic. I really like the cancer. genetic engineering, and pain  topics (though I do think Professor Paulsen definitely needed another lecture given how much material she covered over the nervous system). I didn't really think the Kuru lectures were relevant. I didn't think Poll Everywhere added anything to the class. I think it would have been interesting to have a lecture on vaccination. A really interesting lecture could have been over home remedies / essential oils --the bio or lack thereof behind these "Pintrest" treatments.
This was a very interesting set of issues in current Bio; however, I found the jumping from topic to topic to not really be in such a logical order, so studying for tests was quite scattered.

It was just a science credit that I was taking because I had to. I think that if you want classes to be better, don't make it necessary for bs classes to exist so non-science majors can get a science credit for no real reason.
The "Experience Science" section was a great supplement to the content learned in class, making the content accessible.

The different speakers was a cool experience to have had, but sometimes switching from different learning methods through topics that could be difficult to understand was challenging and made learning harder.
Some lecturers moved through material too fast

This course was a good intro, but there was a big disparity between lecturers. Some were really good and easy to understandothers went lightning fast and I could not follow any of it. The workload is relatively light, but make no mistake, this class is /hard/. The exams are difficult and you actually have to do a good amount of studying the material.

I think that this course exposes students to a variety of topics by different professors who focus in on their specific lectures. Some material is review but much of it delves deeper into the applications of modern science. Lectures were fairly interesting and a good length, and I enjoyed the times we were able to interact during lectures. I think that sections weren't very beneficial as they would loosely relate to the lecture material but hardly prepared us for exams. I would recommend that the sections be more oriented to review the lecture material enough so that we are prepared to answer exam questions.

The strengths were that the course topics were interesting and relevant. The weaknesses included test questions that sometimes didnt reflect what we learned in class and some lectures that were far more confusing than others

Strengths: really cool relation to real world that allows for interdisciplinary study
Weaknesses: lectures could be more engaging
Loved the PowerPoint visuals and the review sessions!

Strengths were definitely the lectures. The lecturers were great and covered a wide array of material. The weaknesses were in the sections. While my TA was great, the sections could have pertained a little more to course material.
Strengths: different lecturers and the section material is interesting

This is an excellent course. Lectures are fascinating and relevant, and the structure of the midterms/paper is really good.

The curriculum could cohere a little more  sometimes lectures felt disconnected from the ones that had preceded them.

I wonder if there is a way to give this course greater unityor to balance it with the general acquaintance with issues in biology we are supposed to attain. 
In any case, this course proved extremely interesting and it was very successful in its goals to help us become interested in and understand contemporary issues in biology
Having many professors was difficult to follow. Each one was different and often they gave us way too much information to follow for an intro science class.
Level of specification in lecture did not match that which was asked on the midterms
They assumed that each student had more of a background in biology than I really did, so it was hard for me to understand concepts from the beginning.

Although this is supposed to be a class for biology beginners, I felt the professors did not explain scientific terms or spoke too quickly so that it was really difficult to understand unless you had a biology background.

make sure you don't repeat the same lecture four times

surprisingly engaging at times!

This is a great course! I really liked how we went over a ton of issues with just hitting the highlights, since it was perfect for someone like me who wants to know a little bit about science but doesn't want to dive in very deeply.
strengths are the sections and weaknesses are the lectures
Would be nice to have less professors.
Too many instructors and too much content.

Strengths: variety of topic, lively section leader, interesting and engaging lectures

Weaknesses: lecturers were not aware of what previous lecturers had taught, so there was some redundant overlap

I liked this course a lot! I thought some of the lecturers were stronger than others. Mainly I think some were able to really synthesize complicated information in a really clear and comprehensive way whereas other lectures were more bogged down with jargon and complicated diagrams etc. But overall I thought this was a really cool course and felt as though I learned a lot.

Strengths: It actually teaches you a surprising amount. 

Weaknesses: Some of the professors lack ... social cognizance. We talked about genetic engineering for at least three lectures but the word 'eugenics' was never uttered once. There should be a lot more social consciousness.
I really enjoyed the section but the lectures sometimes dragged.
Loved the course, I liked the change in teachers. Great TA and section discussion.

I enjoyed the way this course allowed us to explore biology through the lens of ethics, and found the source material to be really interesting. If I had one suggestion for improvement, it sometimes felt as if it was difficult to know what to study for the tests  despite the existence of learning targets, I found that even if I studied all material relevant to the targets there would still be things that surprised me to see on the test.

Some of the lectures were much more complex than others (i.e. neurotransmission, mechanisms of CRISPR-Cas9) given the diverse range of backgrounds in biology enveloped in the student demographic, so maybe slow it down for those lectures. It was an very engaging discussion section that helped me to better understand course material as well as think about the social implications of the biology.

Great professors who are experts in different subjects of biology, and are great teachers.  Nice section supplement that covers the connection between science and politics.  In terms of improvement, it would be great if section could do a brief recap of the lectures each week before delving into planned discussion.

Strengths - wide variety of material means there is something for everyone. Lots of professors with different styles helps keep things fresh. Experimental section is super fun!
Weakness - some professors are less engaging than others.
Strengths: multiple lecturers from different backgrounds, and an array of interesting topics.

I really liked the paper at the end of the term instead of a final exam and the fact that all 3 exams were not cumulative. It made it easier to focus and engage more deeply with the concepts. I think an improvement could be to make discussion sections more engaging.
Strengths- interesting lectures and readings. Weaknesses- the general course schedule did not prepare us well for exams as we never had to practice the scientific concepts until right before

Strengths: it covers a wide range of topics, so it doesn't feel too specialized
Weaknesses: it felt very bottom-heavy (second half seem paced much faster than the first)

Strengths:  interesting subject matter 

Weaknesses:  all of the lectures, or at least 80% of them, were not interesting and often very difficult to follow for someone without a biology background.  The test were extremely difficult, again, for someone without a biology background... I also just found it because the lectures were taught by different people, they were often disjointed and hard to follow.
Really loved section, some of the guest lecturers were a bit dry though. A bit too much "Biology" compared to "The World and US"

The strength of this course is its breadth. A main weakness is the inconsistency between professors, and that exams do not accurately reflect the focus on topics covered in class, instead focusing on things that were no really focused on in class.

Strengths: rotation of instructors keeps it interesting and allows each topic to be taught by the instructor who knows it best. Section is super chill, and the exams aren't cumulative so that's a big plus. The final paper is pretty straightforward too.
Weaknesses: More exam prep would have been great -- which diagrams we need to know (since instructors would often display something for 30 seconds and tell us we didn't need to know how to draw it but it would show up on the exam), how long are answers should be, etc.

-exams were sometimes difficult, required specific answers written one type of way and didn't accept alternative answers that could've also been right but were just worded differently, tested us on material in detail that we skimmed over in lecture 
-section felt very distant from lecture, the issues we discussed were interesting but only relevant to the final paper (not included in the exams at all)
-lectures went really fast, not a lot of time for review
-tried to cram too much material into such a short semester
-falsely advertised as a non-STEM course but actually tested on a lot of science that we learned very quickly
-to improve, i would hold more interactive review sessions, create review sheets with topics/sample or practice test questions

Strengths - interesting topics and committed TAs who give a high level of personal assistance if asked!
Weaknesses - the course is taught by different professors. While some went at a good pace and actually explained everything they were teaching, enabling us to learn, others went through their lectures with speedy jargon and difficult concepts that were not fully explained, leaving students to do a lot of learning and catching up on their own. Luckily, the TAs were very helpful.

Sure. It's in no way a gut. The tests are difficult and will test your knowledge of some pretty in-depth concepts, so it's not a course where you can just wing it on tests (this is a good thing). But if you go to lecture 95% of the time and review the notes before tests, you'll be fine.
Yes! This is a great course for non-stem majors who desire to learn the basics of biology.

I would NOT recommend this course to non-science majors. It's just not the move. Three non-cumulative exams, sections, 2 short discussion papers, lecture, and final paper are all requirements of this course. It requires too mch work for not enough substantive learning/information.
Good science credit if you need one. Low workload, most topics are ethically and societally engaging to think about.
I would definitely recommend this course, especially to humanities students who don't have same science foundations.
I would recommend this class to someone who is trying to fulfill their science requirement. If you don't like biology, I wouldn't take this class because it is basically a straight biology class.

Yes, if they are a science major. With no prior bio classes it's incredibly hard to succeed in this class without a ton of extra work (YouTube videos, online explanations, asking friends in science majors for help, etc.)
Yes. I feel like i have a general understanding of all the topics covered so that I feel informed on these issues to discuss them further.
I mean, If you just want a science and don't care about wasting your time, then go off. This class was pretty easy.
An amazing science gut thats actually a gut. If you took high school bio you could honestly finesse your way through this class without doing anything.
I personally found it difficult, so it depends if the student actually wants to learn about it or is just looking for a Science credit. The material was mostly interesting though.
Yes, it was interesting and I learned a lot
If you need a SC but can't do science, take this course. It does a good amount of science but balances it with social issues as well.

I would recommend this course to another student because it doesn't require much scientific knowledge from beforehand to learn about the material and their applications to modern science. The material is generally interesting, and the workload is very manageable. You are supposed to read some articles for section, but other than that you have no homework other than studying for exams and working on the final paper. I genuinely learned about scientific innovations that are taking place in our world today and the ramifications they could have in the future.
Yes, if you are a non science major and want a relatively low weekly workload.
Yes! Fun science class with cool interdisciplinary elements.
Yes, take it. Even if youre a stem major, this course still provides a lot of big picture insight that you may not otherwise get from a fine-tuned science course.
I would, because its educational but not too time consuming.
Yes; it provides an interesting scientific overview for the non stem person
Yes, absolutely! It was a very good course. I learned a lot of science and I feel much more confident about my basic understanding of biology and of current issues.
Yes good science credit
For a non science major yes
If you need a science credit, be prepared to study really hard for the tests. Its a pretty hard A to get.
Yes, i would recommend this class to a student who is willing to go to lectures, put in the work right before the exam, and had little to no knowledge in biology.
Absolutely! Great and interesting class for non stem
yes! good comprehensive overview of key bio issues
Yes, definitely, especially if you are not a STEM major.
No because the lectures were extremely u helpful for exams and sections
No, it was too general and confusing

Yes! I learned so many details about so many random scientific topics, so it's nice to have those fun facts in my toolkit! Some lecturers are more fun than others, but entering class unaware of who or what was being taught made coming to lecture every week a little more fun. Section was very fun, in that we only had to refer to lecture material to strengthen sociopolitical arguments. Talking about the societal impact of scientific breakthroughs made me think critically about my own conception of "health" and broader questions as they relate to the survival of the human race.
Yup! This is a great science course for a humanities major.

Sure! As someone whose bio teacher quit halfway through the year, this class helped me overcome a learning curve! Only if you're non-STEM should you take this though, it's absolutely redundant and unnecessary if you're any type of bio major.

Yes, if you've never taken a proper biology course like me. This will give you the background knowledge to be able to understand and think about current biological topics and their ethical, economic, political implications.
Yes.
Yes! Good for non science people

If the student was looking for a simpler science course that taught them about the applications of biology outside of the typical scope of biology textbook ;earning, I would recommend the course. It was challenging at times, but overall easy to follow. But, it also varies depending on your science background.
This is a great class for any non-STEM student looking to fulfill a science credit.  Not only is it manageable, but it is interesting and very approachable.

YES, especially if you are not a STEM major. I learned a lot of new biological concepts beyond what you would know in AP biology. I highly recommend the experimental section--we get to visit different scientific sites around campus, including the Cushing Brain collection, Botanical Gardens, and
Yes - for non science majors this is a fairly basic but comprehensive class that covers an array of interesting topics.

Its a great class for humanities majors who need a science credit. Youre learning scientific concepts in lecture, but the sections are a place for discussing the ethical implications of the course material.
yes
Yes, I thought it was a good science credit to take for students who do not necessarily want to major in a science.
It is a great science credit for non majors
Very good science credit
Yes as an interesting class if they need a science credit
I would not recommend this as a SC gutit was much more difficult than I anticipated or had heard from other students

No, Regardless if youre taking this class for an easier science credit, or you were really interested in the modern implications of basic biology, I dont think youll get either of those things and less you have a strong background in biology.
Of course! All this scientific information is really really helpful for just being an educated citizen.
Yeah
I would recommend this -- you learn a ton, and the workload is incredibly manageable.

Yes. Not super gutty, but not hard. The workload comes in bursts, with 3 exams and a final paper. But it is pretty manageable and definitely not something you have to be highly engaged with every week.
maybe (only to meet distributional requirement)
Yes - very good, approachable level for a non-science person, while still allowing you to learn what felt like valuable and relevant content.
